title: How Hard is it to Create an Animation?

replies.body:
Greetings Jaune.

I'm a publishing lead on a team heavily invested in things you call animation.  My hands aren't the ones that do the fine craft art, but perhaps I can help answer your questions.  

Most recently our team worked on "The Climb" and "The Wrath of Zaun".  If you're more interested in 2D animation instead of 3D our team has a good amount of experience in that as well.

I can't guarantee that I'm allowed to discuss everything, but I'll answer what I can.

It's okay. Trade secrets-confidentiality and all of that, right? XD

Still, thanks for taking time to answer my questions. Uh, I'm not too sure how well I'll be able to articulate what I want to know, so my questions might sound too broad or convoluted or stuff like that.

Well, I guess my first question would have to be about 3D modeling. How do the textures get made? The grains you use for the stones in the background, the many minuscule scratches on plate armor, the individual strands of hair, the little fibers you can see sticking up from Yasuo's cloak on his shoulders when he stands up in "The Climb"-how do they get made? Or am I just completely overthinking things and it's some type of preset that even beginner 3D model creators can do?
Star Guardian: New Horizon anime short is the best.

I'd still put my money on either Annie: Origins bc they had to partially paint each frame and Lux: Binding Light bc it was cell and used quick sketches to make something awesome. Though, I thought that the lighting and light effects looked awesome in the Star Guardian animation, especially with that sunrise.

Now, people can guess how much work has gone into this 37 seconds of animation. I don't know, but I'd like to know lol.

(It's the preview/trailer for Violet Evergarden, that is currently airing. I have not watched it, but some say the anime so far keeps this quality quite closely. I shudder at the prospect.)

VIOLET EVERGARDEN HAS SOME OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL VISUALS I HAVE EVER SEEN. I've seen the first two episodes and if you know Makoto Shinkai's Kimi no Nawa, then it's around that level of beauty. The kind where you're just completely riveted throughout the entire episode with wide eyes and a stunned expression because of how good the visuals are. I might just be exaggerating because I tend to get too excited with animations, but dang. It's nothing to scoff at.

I haven't watched Magus yet though, but I hear it's good and I know the plot (more or less). Now, if only homework didn't exist and the weekend would just roll around already . . . XD

My world has been broadened. Wow, I honestly did not expect for the animation rough draft to be in a cell-animation style, and on paper too! I always thought that there would be fewer frames involved and that they used tablets to draw them digitally. TY man!

> [{quoted}](name=Jaune,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=KL69T9Yk,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2018-03-13T11:08:34.401+0000)
>
> My world has been broadened. Wow, I honestly did not expect for the animation rough draft to be in a cell-animation style, and on paper too! I always thought that there would be fewer frames involved and that they used tablets to draw them digitally. TY man!

It varies from studio to studio. Different studios have their strengths and weakness depending on the kind of philosophy they adhere to, some may be more traditionalist while other may use more varying degrees of digital assistance.

Though in general, the drafts and sketches of anime are still done on paper first. This is still kept because hand-made animation flow more organically and typically able to be more complex thanks to the malleable nature of hand-drawing, which is something CGI may lack if no fat budget and significant talent is put into reassuring natural movement. CGI hence is mostly used in anime either as a budget cutting measure used at the expense of quality, but sometimes its disadvantage is actually used for beneficial results, such as if you actually need frantic and janky movement, they sometimes use CG model as a base to draw 2D arts on, because CG characters by default do not have fluid movement (this is how the titans in Attack on Titans are drawn). Many ways to play around things.

That's still amazing though! And the fact that pink paper gets used for corrections reminds me of onion skins in animation. But still, seeing how an animation goes from rough draft to finished product is amazing! (Also, can we please talk about how fast Yoshinari was working? I thought it was a time lapse! 0.0)

In case someone is interested to sit for an hour watching a video...

I know what I'm going to be doing tonight and it's definitely not homework assignments. +U+

Anything can be easy to do if you dont put effort, but it doesnt mean that it will be good... And anything can be easy with enough practice, but it doesnt mean that doing that is easy per se. 

Cooking can be easy, but creating a great meal that tastes good is not that easy... the same can be said about anything, including animation.

https://i.imgur.com/CjT2I2f.png

See? Drawing is easy... but making a good drawn is not. For example.

Haha, 'practice makes perfect' at it's finest. XD

But I get what you're saying, man. When it comes down to it, the harder you train, the easier the battle.

And in the case of animation and art, the more things you try to draw and the more you keep animating, the better it looks. And it helps if you have A LOT of time. I tried drawing a comic panel once just to see what it was like (fully colored btw) and burned out on the fourth panel. If anyone ever said that drawing doesn't require any stamina and it's easy, then I BEG TO DIFFER.
